Abstract A novel strategy to precisely detect or monitor various biomaterials in living cells poses paramount importance in understanding cellular processes. Graphene, a newly emerged twodimensional carbon material, has been widely utilized for biosensors owing to its multifarious characteristics including mechanical, electrical, and optical properties (e.g. stability, conductivity, fluorescence quenching and photoluminescence). In addition, graphene derivatives and their innate characteristics, such as biocompatibility low cytotoxicity and water solubility have facilitated the use of graphene-based materials for live cell biosensing, wherein graphene is utilized as a core material by itself or in combination with other functional nanomaterials to load target-specific probes, fluorescent dyes, and other signaling molecules. Such graphene-based hybrid nanomaterials have been employed to detect various cellular entities in living cells, including ions, biomolecules, genetic molecules, proteins, enzymes, and even whole cells. The following review will discuss a number of previous studies in which graphene-based hybrid constructs were used for live cell biosensing, and their potential applications in cancer research and stem cell therapy.
Key words: Graphene, Graphene oxide, Graphene quantum dots, Graphene hybrid nanoparticles, Live cell sensing

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Owing to the innate structural and compositional complexity, the precise characterization and analysis of biological cells have been extremely challenging. Several traditional analytical methods, including immunostaining, western blotting, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and fluorescence-assisted cell sorting (FACS) have been proven its utility for the characterization of various types of cells and organs (Chung and Deisseroth 2013; Chung et al. 2013b; Gupta et al. 1996; McDonald et al. 2010). However, those techniques generally entail invasive/destructive steps, such as cell lysis and fixation, rendering them impractical for live cell analysis. Cells are often termed as ‘living factories’ because they undergo constant metabolism. This attributes to the importance of detecting and monitoring the behavior of materials in interest inside the living cells to fully understand various unidentified cellular activities, and such information will offer multitudinous opportunities in both cancer research and cell-based regenerative therapy (Diesner et al. 2010; Notingher et al. 2002; Tsikritsis et al. 2015). To this end, numerous studies have reported efficient methods to detect specific target materials in viable cells including proteins/enzymes (Choi et al. 2009; Lee et al. 2015; Sharonov et al. 2005), miRNAs (George et al. 2013; Larkey et al. 2014; Sadhu and Winssinger 2013), mRNAs (Alexander et al. 2011; Liu et al. 2012; McClellan et al. 2015; Qiu et al. 2013), neurotransmitters (Hettie et al. 2013; Qian et al. 2015), and heavy metal ions (Aydin et al. 2014; Zhang et al. 2015; Zhou et al. 2014). However, their analysis methods were mostly based on fluorescence, fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), Raman spectroscopy, and plasmonic resonance energy transfer (PRET), all of which require signal-generating molecules (e.g. fluorescence, Raman scattering and plasmonic resonance) or other factors that receive and relay transferred signals from neighboring materials. Consequently, functional nanoparticles with biological or chemical receptors capable of
capturing target molecules have gained increasingly prominent attention for its wide spectrum of utility and application.
In addition to hybrid nanoparticles in live cell biosensing, graphene, a two-dimensional material made of carbon, has also recently gained considerable attention in the field of biotechnology (Kang et al. 2012; Kim et al. 2015; Nanda et al. 2015; Peng et al. 2012; Shah et al. 2014; Shin et al. 2014). Owing to its excellent electrical conductivity, optical transparency, and mechanical stability, graphene has mostly been utilized for electronic, electrochemical, and optical applications (Novoselov et al. 2012). However, recent studies have revealed that graphene and its derivatives including graphene oxide (GO) entail a number of favorable features particularly advantageous to biological applications such as excellent biocompatibility, tunable amphiphilicity, high drug loading capacity, and precise control over its size and shape (Solanki et al. 2011; Yin et al. 2013; Yin et al. 2015). In light of its multifarious characteristics, graphene was reported to have abounding application potentials in fluorescence-based detection for it can strongly quench the fluorescence signals from neighboring fluorophores, and generate them in a way similar to quantum dots (QDs) (Gao et al. 2014; Liu et al. 2014a; Zor et al. 2015). Moreover, owing to the distinct carbon honey comb structure, graphene can also generate specific Raman signals in the D, G, and 2D bands, which attribute to its substantial aptitude for live cell imaging either alone or in combination with other functional nanoparticles with abilities to induce surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) (Liu et al. 2013b). The unique structural characteristics of graphene entails that it can also attract single-stranded oligonucleotides and release them in the presence of their complementary sequence or target molecules, which enable sensitive detection of various materials in living cells (Liu et al. 2013a) and even the detection of harmful bacteria (Ling et al. 2015; Zhu et al. 2015b). However, despite the efficacy of graphene
and graphene-based nanomaterials in live cell biosensing, the lack of comprehensive reviews, pertaining to this topic, impedes the potential application of graphene-based hybrid nanomaterials for live cell biosensing.
Hence, in the following review, we will discuss the current applications of graphene-based hybrid materials, with a particular focus on their usage for sensing and monitoring various biological materials in living cells (Figure 1). Initially, we will summarize different types of graphene derivatives (e.g. graphene, GO, GQDs and graphene hybrid nanoparticles) to provide necessary information pertaining to the advantages in using graphene compounds in biosensors. Then we will highlight a number of previous studies that have incorporated these materials as a core component for in situ detection of various biomaterials, ranging from ions (e.g. mercury, manganese, fluoride, copper and ferric ions) biomolecules (e.g. neurotransmitters, glutathione, salic acid, hydrogen peroxide and nitric oxide), genetic materials (e.g. nucleotides, mRNA, miRNA, DNA and telomeres), proteins/enzymes (e.g. cytochrome C, proteases, phospholipase and matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)), to whole cells (e.g. cancer cells, cancer stem cells, normal cells, and stem cells). It is our hope that this review will shed light to the use of graphene-based hybrid nanomaterials for live cell biosensing, and ultimately facilitate finding effective tools, drugs, and cell-based therapies to overcome some of conventional barriers in treating numerous incurable diseases. (Preferred position for Figure 1)

sections.heading: 2. Graphene-based materials for live cell biosensing
sections.text:
Due to a wide variety of their unique optical characteristics, graphene derivatives have been utilized as fluorescence quenchers, fluorophores, electrical signal enhancers, and cell-friendly materials for enhancing cell penetration of functional nanoparticles or cell adhesion on electrode
surfaces. In order to exploit such advantageous properties to the full extent, GO, GQDs, and graphene hybrid nanoparticles should be precisely fabricated, and their physicochemical properties must be modified accordingly. Here, we will discuss several synthesis methods to prepare different types of graphene derivatives. The discussion will be divided into three different categories based on different graphene derivatives used in live cell biosensing: graphene and graphene oxide, graphene quantum dots, and graphene hybrid nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Graphene and graphene oxide
sections.text:
There are several different ways to prepare graphene including: i) chemical vapor deposition (CVD), ii) mechanical exfoliation, and iii) chemical or electrochemical reduction of GO (Yin et al. 2013; Yin et al. 2015). Graphene, prepared on Si or metal substrates via CVD, has shown the highest purity in carbon component and arrangement (honeycomb structure), and has shown the highest electron carrier mobility, reaching 2000-4000 cm 2 V -1 s -1 (Emtsev et al. 2009). However, GO has had broader biological applications due to the highly hydrophobic nature of graphene (Chung et al. 2013a). The most useful feature of GO for biosensing is its ability to quench numerous fluorophores (e.g. organic dyes, upconversion nanoparticles and QDs), in part via long-range resonance energy transfer (Gao et al. 2014). This unique property of GO, as well as its low cytotoxicity and high water solubility, makes GO a highly desirable material for live cell biosensing. On the other hand, GO can be further converted to reduced GO (rGO) by eliminating the hydroxyl groups present on the surface of GO via chemical, electrochemical or thermal reduction processes (Compton and Nguyen 2010; Dreyer et al. 2010). rGO has closer resemblance to graphene in terms of structural and electrical characteristics. However, due to the lack of hydroxyl groups, rGO shows reduced solubility in cell culture medium, which limits its
uses mostly for substrate-based approaches rather than nanoparticle-based approaches for the electrical, electrochemical and optical characterization of cellular biomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.2 Graphene quantum dots
sections.text: In addition to conventional or newly-discovered fluorescence materials such as fluorescent dyes, QDs, and carbon dots, researchers recently proposed the potential use of graphene derivatives for fluorescence nanomaterials, termed ‘graphene quantum dots (GQDs)’ (Baker and Baker 2010; Li et al. 2013b). Unlike graphene or GO, which retain strong fluorescencequenching ability, GQDs possess strong photoluminescence because of the quantum confinement effect and edge effect; the luminescence efficiency is highly affected by preparation method, size, shape, and surface characteristics (Li et al. 2013b). GQDs are less than 30 nm thick with a single layer or tens of layers of graphene (Li et al. 2013b; Zhu et al. 2015a). Various methods have also been used to synthesize GQDs, such as chemical synthesis, reduction of GO, cage-opening of C60, electron beam lithography, microwave-assisted hydrothermal method (MAH), and ultrasonic exfoliation (Chua et al. 2015; Tang et al. 2012; Tang et al. 2014; Zhao et al. 2014). Generally, GQDs contain carboxylic acid groups at their edges that are similar to GO, which make them highly soluble in water and suitable for further modification with other functional molecules such as organic/inorganic and biological components. Compared to other conventional fluorescent materials, especially QDs, GQDs are conclusively more preferable for live cell sensing owing to their excellent biocompatibility, low cytotoxicity, and environmentfriendliness.

sections.heading: 2.3. Graphene hybrid nanoparticles
sections.text: Nanoparticle-embedded graphene sheets are the most common form of graphene hybrid nanoparticles (Kong et al. 2009). Currently, there are two conventional ways available to produce such platform: growing the nanoparticles on the surface of graphene (in situ fabrication), and attaching nanoparticles to graphene via chemical bonding/electrostatic interaction. Moreover, it was also reported that various metals (e.g. Ag, Au and Pt) and metal oxide nanoparticles (e.g. MnO2, Fe3O4, TiO2, Cu2O and ZnO) could be incorporated to the surface modification process of graphene or GO (Yin et al. 2015). In the case of in situ fabrication, the nanoparticles are usually generated on the surface of graphene/GO by adding reducing agents (e.g. ethylene glycol and sodium borohydride) in combination with metallic salts (Muszynski et al. 2008). However, a hydrothermal synthetic method has also been widely used to generate graphene-metal oxide nanoparticle composites (Bai and Shen 2012). This method entails a number of advantages including high capacitance, enhanced electron conductivity, and increased surface area compared to graphene alone. In addition, electrochemical technique could also be employed for synthesizing graphene hybrid constructs. Instead of adding reducing agents, an electrical potential is applied to the graphene-modified electrodes in the presence of metallic saltcontaining electrolytes, resulting in the stable growth of NPs on the electrodes (Ding et al. 2014). Lastly, several studies have recently introduced graphene-encapsulated nanoparticles and its fabrication method where graphene or GO particles are added to the surface of NPs to form an encapsulating shell. To be specific, Silica, cobalt oxide, gold, silver and titanium oxide NPs have been effectively encapsulated with graphene or GO mostly via electrostatic interaction between GO (negatively charged) and NPs (positively charged) (Gao et al. 2015; Kim et al. 2013; Yang et al. 2010; Zhang et al. 2013b).

sections.heading: 3. Graphene-based hybrid nanoparticles for live cell biosensing
sections.text: As mentioned earlier, owing to their excellent biocompatibility, water solubility, and unique interactions with specific molecules, such as fluorophores and oligonucleotides, graphene derivatives (GDs), mostly in conjunction with various functional nanoparticles, have been widely utilized to detect cytosolic environments of living cells. In the following subsection, we will highlight a number of previous studies that have reported the use of graphene-based materials to detect specific molecules of interest including different types of ions, genetic materials, biomolecules, and proteins/enzymes, as well as their potential applicability as live cell biosensors (Table 1). (Preferred position for Table 1)

sections.heading: 3.1 Ion sensing in living cells
sections.text:
Ions are essential to a variety of cellular functions such as neurotransmission, neuromuscular transmission, nutrient uptake, and enzymatic activities (Takeda 2003). However, the heavy metal ions from the external environment can interfere with these crucial cellular activities, and consequently are considered to be a debilitating threat to the human health (de Silva et al. 1997). One of the most predominant heavy metal-related illnesses is mercury poisoning. Mercury (II) ion (Hg 2+ ) is one of the most abundant pollutants worldwide, and is known to be highly toxic to cells, owing to its high affinity for cysteine residues (thiol groups) in peptide sequences. Consequently, they result in structural deformations and dysfunctions of proteins/enzymes (Valko et al. 2005). Therefore, considering the paramount impact that such sensors could endow to both public health and environmental studies, it would be most propitious to develop a biosensing platform that enables sensitive and selective detection of mercury ions in ex vivo and in vitro conditions.
In 2014, Yan et al. reported an interesting method to detect mercury ions in different concentrations; they used highly photoluminescent carbon nanodots (CDs) which can be effectively quenched by heavy metal ions including Hg 2+ (Yan et al. 2014). The authors synthesized two different types of CDs, 2-ethylenediamine (CD-1) and N-(b-aminoethyl)-gaminopropyl methyldimethoxysilane (AEAPMS) (CD-2). Both CD-1 and CD-2 showed higher selectivity for Hg 2+ over other metal ions, including Al 3+ , Cd 2+ , Ce 3+ , Fe 3+ , Cu 2+ , K + , Na + , Mn 2+ , Au + and Au 3+ . The limit of detection (LOD) of both CDs were 226nM and 845nM, respectively. Furthermore, Hg 2+ was also detected in living fibroblast cells (NIH-3T3) using the same method when incubated with 20μg/mL of CDs. They exhibited very low toxicity, resulting in 92% cell viability with a concentration of 200μg/mL CD after 24 hours of incubation. In 2015, Hua et al. reported a simple method for synthesizing graphene hybrid material based on core-satellite hybrid spheres with high efficiency in visualizing Hg2+, termed ‘graphene quantum dots (GQDs) (Hua et al. 2015). The hybrid nanoparticle consists of red light-emitting internal fluorescence material (CdTe quantum dots), silica nanoparticles as a QD-carrier, and a blue light-emitting outer GQD layer that interacts with Hg 2+ . Owing to the strong fluorescencequenching ability of Hg 2+ , the color of hybrid nanoparticles gradually changed from blue to red in response to the concentrations of Hg 2+ , which enabled sensitive and selective detection of Hg 2+ with an excellent built-in correction for environmental interference. The authors claimed that the developed sensing system is capable of measuring Hg 2+ in a broad linear range (10 – 22 nm) with an LOD of 3.3 nM. The GQDs were also adapted in studies by Liu et al., who used fluorescence material (rhodamine)-conjugated GQDs (GQDs-SR) to detect Hg 2+ based on fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) where GQDs served as energy donors and a rhodamine derivative was used as an energy acceptor when Hg 2+ was spotted (Liu et al. 2015b).
Similar to other types of GQD-based approaches, GQDs-SR have been shown to be felicitous for imaging intracellular Hg 2+ because of their low cytotoxicity, biocompatibility, and good water solubility with a detection range of 0.6 to 12 μM (LOD: 0.23μM). In addition, a DNA-modified GQD was also recently reported to be effective in detecting Hg 2+ in living cells wherein thyminerich DNA sequences quenched the fluorescence of GQDs in the presence of Hg 2+ (Zhao et al. 2015). It was found that Hg2+ in the cytosolic environment resulted in a T-T mismatch hairpin structure of DNA-Hg2+, and attributed to the decrease in the fluorescence intensity of GQDs, owing to the strong interaction between Hg2+ and DNA thymine bases,. (Preferred position for Figure 2)
In addition to its efficacy in detecting toxic metal ions, a number of studies have investigated the use of graphene-based materials for monitoring other ions, such as manganese, fluoride, copper and ferric ions. In 2013, Mao et al. reported the use of bipyrene-functionalized graphene to detect manganese (II) ions in living cells based on ‘Turn-On’ fluorescence signals (Mao et al. 2013) (Figure 2a). Moreover, 1,2-bis-(2-pyren-1-ylmethylamino-ethoxy) ethane (NPEY) was synthesized and adsorbed to the surface of graphene nanosheets (GNs) via π-π stacking, which served as a “turn-on” fluorescence material for sensing intracellular Mn 2+ . The fluorescence signal was only received when Mn 2+ was bound to the NPEY, indicating the recovery of the FL signals of NPEY via photoinduced electron transfer (PET). On the other hand, Wang et al. also reported detection of fluoride ions in living cells using GO and fluorescent chemodosimeter molecules (Wang et al. 2014). They reportedly coupled a new fluoride ion-specific fluorescent chemodosimeter termed ‘FC-A’ with GO. The GO/FC-A hybrid construct was found to have a reaction rate constant 5-folds larger than FC-A but response time (30 min) shorter than FC-A (4 hours). Lastly, in 2015, Sun et al. reported an effective live cell imaging of copper, which is one
of the essential trace elements responsible for a number of physiological processes in the human body (Sun et al. 2015) (Figure 2b). They employed blue light-emitting GQDs and yellow lightemitting CdTe QDs as internal standards and probes for copper ions, respectively. Owing to the stark color contrast between copper ion-specific red shift of CdTe QDs and continuous blue FL signals from the GQD/GSH construct, the GQD hybrid construct showed high selectivity toward copper with an LOD of 53nM, and was proven to be suitable for the intracellular imaging of copper ions.
As a summary of this section, GO or GQD are highly efficient materials for ion-sensing in living cells. Their excellent physicochemical characteristics, such as biocompatibility, surface properties, water solubility, and low cytotoxicity give rise to such favorable ion-sensing capability, which could be further enhanced when combined with proper reporters or capturing moieties.

sections.heading: 3.2 Oligonucleotide sensing in living cells
sections.text:
It was reported that Graphene derivatives shows an exceptional binding affinity for single strand oligonucleotides (SSOs) (Gao et al. 2014). The interaction between each SSOs is stronger than the interaction between an SSO and the graphene surface. This causes the SSOs to bind to respective complementary sequences, generate double-stranded oligonucleotides, and consequently detach from the surface of graphene derivatives. Since its discovery, a large volume of studies have reported the use of graphene-SSO constructs to detect intracellular genetic materials by exploiting the small size and biocompatibility of graphene derivatives.
In 2012, Piao et al. introduced an interesting study using a molecular beacon (MB) as a probe, and graphene nanoparticles (GN) as a nanoquencher, which enabled in situ mRNA monitoring in cancer cells (Piao et al. 2012) (Figure 3a). To be specific, a fluorophore (FAM)-containing MB
was conjugated with a pyrene molecule and mixed with graphene nanoparticles, and the π-π interaction between pyrene and GN resulted in a MB-GN hybrid structure. Because of the strong fluorescence-quenching ability of GN, the fluorescence signal was only recovered when MB hybridized with its complementary sequence. The detection range of the developed sensing platform was reported to be 0.5 – 2.5 nM with an LOD of 2nM, accentuating its desirable sensitivity. The MB-GN nanoparticles were tested with human breast cancer cells (MCF-7) and demonstrated its outstanding performance in monitoring the surviving gene expression levels in viable cells (Figure 3b). In addition to the use of MBs in detecting mRNA expression in living cells, Li et al. also reported an interesting study using fluorophore-modified GO to detect DNA in both in vitro and in vivo conditions (Li et al. 2013a). The fluorescence molecule, (tris(1,10phenanthroline)ruthenium(II) dichloride) [Ru(phen)3cl2], was physically adsorbed to the surface of GO via π-π stacking (GO-Ru) and was used as a probe to detect intracellular DNA sequences. Owing to the interaction between DNA and Ru(phen)3cdl2, which is stronger than that between GO and Ru(phen)3cl2, Ru(phen)3cl2 was released from the surface of GO in the presence of target DNA. The release of Ru(phen)3cl2 resulted in the recovery of a strong Ru(phen)3cl2 fluorescence signal that was detected by conventional fluorescence microscopy. The detection range of the sensing platform was reported to be 0-70 μM with an LOD of 33nM. Remarkably, GO-Ru easily penetrated the cell membranes owing to the outstanding biocompatibility of GO, and successfully detected DNA in viable cells even in the presence of various interfering molecules such as human serum albumin (HSA), bovine serum albumin (BSA), collagen, protease, lysozyme, and chymotrypsin.
In addition to the use of fluorescence molecules or MB in the accurate detection of genetic materials in living cells, de Avila et al. recently introduced a new concept that is useful in
detecting miRNA expression at the single cell level using an ssNDA-containing GO/gold nanowire (AuNWs) hybrid structure (de Avila et al. 2015) where AuNWs were responsible for enhancing the uptake efficiency of the developed GO hybrid materials. When the nanomaterials crossed the cellular membrane, the hybridization of the labelled ssDNA with the complementary sequence caused the displacement of dye-labeled ssDNA from the GO which exposed the target miRNA (miRNA-21) for detection. Two types of cancer cells, MCF-7 and HeLa, were subjected to the developed sensing technique and showed clear differences in miRNA-21, whose difference could be perceived using fluorescence microscopy. (Preferred position for Figure 3)
It is not surprising that most of the previous studies using GO or its derivatives for live cell biosensing co-utilize SSO (e.g. ssDNA, ssRNA, aptamers, or MB) as probes for target molecules since the interaction between GO and SSO is highly unique and such affinity is difficult to obtain using other nanomaterials. However, peptide nucleic acid (PNA) have been recently tested for its detection performance in place of ssDNAs/RNAs, because the neutral pH (around 7) of PNA could diminish its repulsive behavior around the negatively-charged GO.
In 2013, Ryoo et al. fabricated PNA-loaded nanoGO (PANGO) that was proven to be useful for the quantitative detection of multiple miRNAs in living cells (Ryoo et al. 2013) (Figure 3c). The core mechanism behind the detection of miRNAs was the same as the previous study concerning the use of SSO-GO; however, the advantageous characteristics of PNAs allowed the PANGO platform to show superior performance in sequence specificity, loading efficiency, and resistance to enzyme-mediated degradation. It also showed a remarkable LOD of 1 pM for when used to sense three different miRNAs in living cells. In addition, Sabale et al. also reported a PNA-GO hybrid construct to detect human telomeric repeats based on turn-on fluorescence
(Sabale et al. 2014). Given the paramount importance of Q-quadruplex structures, the developed PNA-GO platform is expected to have an abounding spectrum of utility. Its capacity in detecting longer telomeric DNA repeats distinguishes itself from other previously reported studies since they are limited by G-quadruplexes with shorter telomere sequences.
Therefore, it is highly likely that hybrid structures, composed of graphene derivatives and SSO-based sensing probes (or PNAs), would be widely used to investigate the expression of biological materials in living cells for mRNAs, miRNAs, DNAs, and telomeres in a nondestructive and non-invasive manner.

sections.heading: 3.3 Biomolecular sensing in living cells
sections.text:
In addition to detecting ion and oligonucleotide in living cells, graphene-based materials are also capable of investigating a number of biomolecules present in the intracellular environment. Currently, some of the most frequently targeted biomolecules are nucleotides such as adenosine5'-triphosphate (ATP) and guanosine-5'-triphosphate (GTP). They impose considerable importance in a number of cell activities such as microtubule assembly, protein secretion, cell-tocell interaction/communication, etc (Saraste et al. 1990). In 2013, Wang et al. reported a new method to simultaneously monitor ATP and GTP in living cells (Wang et al. 2013), where fluorescence-tagged DNA/RNA aptamers, initially immobilized on GO nanosheets (GO-nS), selectively bind to ATP and GTP. The authors concluded that GO-nS/aptamer hybrids are proven for its expediency snot only for enhancing cell uptake with low cytotoxicity, but also for protecting aptamer cleavage from enzymatic activities. It was reportedly concluded that GOnS/aptamer hybrids enabled highly selective, simultaneous in situ monitoring of ATP and GTP in viable cells. Liu et al. also introduced a GO/aptamer hybrid material-based platform to detect intracellular ATP (Liu et al. 2014b) (Figure 4a). Unlike the previous report, Liu et al. covalently
attached aptamer beacons to the carboxylic groups of GO that were not released when bound to target molecules. The coupling efficiency of these aptamer-GO complexes was similar to that of aptamer physically adsorbed on the GO surface; however, the covalently bound aptamer was more resistive to non-specific probe displacement by proteins, as well as to DNase-1-mediated cleaving activity. The platform could detect ATP levels from 0.125 to 2 mM, and maintained excellent detection capacity in cytosolic environments, proving its ability to detect various intracellular metabolites with enhanced stability (Figure 4b). In addition, Yi et al. reported a GO/aptamer nanosensor capable of detecting ATP using two-photon excitation (TPE) with a near-infrared (NIR) energy source (Yi et al. 2014). NIR light is known for its adequacy in biosensing applications owing to its lower tissue autofluorescence, reduced photobleaching, deeper tissue penetration, and higher spatial resolution (Helmchen and Denk 2005). This sensing platform implemented a TR-dye-conjugated aptamer/GO construct to detect ATP levels from 10 μM to 3mM with an LOD of 0.5 μM, and demonstrated high selectivity for ATP molecules over other nucleoside triphosphates such as CTP, TUP and GTP. Remarkably, this nanosensor also successfully isolated the presence of ATP in both in vitro (HeLa cells) and in vivo (zebrafish) conditions, indicating that graphene-based hybrid sensing platform in conjunction with NIR twophoton microscopy is highly promising for in vivo imaging of target biomolecules.
Recently, neurotransmitters (NTs) have gained its fair share of attention as a target for detection using graphene hybrid materials. NTs serve as one of the most important biochemical entities in the human body for its function as the ‘language’ of neuronal cells that enable signal transmission between cells. Their importance as a signal molecule often puts NTs responsible for several serious diseases/disorders (e.g. Parkinson’s diseases, psychosis, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) when NT-producing neuronal cells malfunction or become damaged.
Hence, a direct detection of NTs from neuronal cells in highly sensitive and selective manner has become increasingly important for early diagnosis of neurological diseases. In 2014, Jeon et al. reported a novel chemical method to modulate photoluminescence of GO to different neurotransmitters (NTs) that enabled selective detection of specific NTs without using antibodies (Jeon et al. 2014). GO was modified with nitrotriacetic acid (NTA) and further chelated with four different metal ions, which produced distinguished PL responses to different NTs. Interestingly, the GO-Cu 2+ combination was able to selectively detect norepinephrine (NorEpi) within a concentration range of 10-320 nM. Owing to the high sensitivity, selectivity, and excellent biocompatibility of GO, the developed metal-chelated GO successfully detected NorEpi secreted from living PC12 cells under stimulation with KCl which was later proven to be consistent with the results from ELISA and electrochemical methods. (Preferred position for Figure 4)
In addition to neurotransmitter detection, several reports have been presented the potential applicability of graphene derivatives to detect glutathione (GSH), a well-known molecule responsible for the prevention of reactive oxygen species (ROS)-mediated damages to important cellular components (Estrela et al. 2006). Specifically, Ju et al. introduced nitrogen-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) wherein Hg(II) ions on the N-GQD surface impede the fluorescent signals generated by N-GQDs (Ju et al. 2014). However, due to the preferred hybridization of Hg(II) and GSH with a more stable Hg(II)-S bond, the fluorescence signals could be retrieved in the presence of GSH, allowing GSH to be monitored simultaneously. The LOD of this platform was 87 nM and, owing to the bright luminescence of N-GQDs and their low cytotoxicity, the expression level of GSH in living HeLa cells could be successfully visualized. In the same year, Zhang et al. also reported graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4)
nanosheet-MnO2 sandwich composites that are capable of detecting GSH in aqueous solutions, as well as in viable cells (Zhang et al. 2014a). Since MnO2 degrades in the presence of GSH, the quenched fluorescence of g-C3N4 can be recovered by GSH expression, resulting in the emission of strong fluorescence that indicates the distribution of GSH in living cells. In 2015, Yang et al. introduced selenium-doped graphene quantum dots that function as reversible fluorescent switches to detect oxidative hydroxyl radicals and GSH (Yang et al. 2015). Owing to the reversible oxidation of C-Se groups and the reduction of Se-Se groups, the fluorescence of hybrid nanomaterials was quenched and recovered, enabling sensitive detection of hydroxyl radicals and GSH in living HeLa cells (Figure 4c).
As illustrated above, most previous studies applied fluorescence-based methods for live cell biosensing of biomolecules of interest. Interestingly, in 2015, Liu et al. reported a new electrochemical technique to detect sialic acid (SA), the overexpression of which is associated with a number of debilitating diseases (Liu et al. 2015a). Two different particles were prepared for signal amplification; a 3-aminophenylboronic acid (APBA)-conjugated carbon nanosphere (CNS-APBA) that is capable of recognizing SA, and a horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-modified gold nanoparticle (Au-HRP NPs). Since HRP can convert aniline monomers to polyaniline in the presence of hydrogen peroxide, these two nanoparticles can synergistically enhance electrical signals, which can be translated to SA expression in living cells. Based on this method, the authors confirmed the difference in electrical signals from MCF-7 and BGC-823 cells with a LOD of 25 cells/mL and 800 cells/mL for MCF-7 and BGC-823 cells, respectively.
Therefore, we could expect that graphene-based nanomaterials will soon encounter an exponential rise in its reputation in detecting various biomolecules including nucleic acid monomers, neurotransmitters, GSH, and even cancer biomarkers.

sections.heading: 3.4 Protein/Enzyme sensing in living cells
sections.text:
The final category pertains to the detection of proteins/enzymes, which are another class of essential biomaterials that play a crucial role in maintaining various cellular activities. Until now, it has been reported that a wide variety of cancer markers and enzymes (e.g. cytochrome C, proteases and phospholipase) could be subjected to detection using graphene-based multifunctional nanoparticles. In 2013, Hu et al first reported a hybrid structure composed of reduced GO, silver nanoparticles, and folic acid that is capable of binding to folic acid receptors on cancer cells (Hu et al. 2013) (Figure 5a). Specifically, the rGO-AgNPs were first synthesized by using poly (N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) as a reductant and folic acid molecules were physically adsorbed onto the rGO-AgNPs construct. Folic acid is a vital molecule involved in major cell activities including proliferation and migration; it is overexpressed in many cancers including ovary, kidney, lung, breast, and brain cancer. In light of such significance, the fabrication of folic acid-targeting nanomaterials is valuable not only for distinguishing tumorigenic cells from normal cells for cancer diagnosis, but also for developing cancer type-specific chemotherapeutic agents. Interestingly, owing to the unique Raman signals of graphene/GO such as D, G and 2D bands in conjunction with Raman-enhancing materials (Ag NPs), the Raman signals assigned to the D and G bands were stronger in HeLa cells (cancer) than in normal cells (A549). (Preferred position for Figure 5)
Although cancer cell diagnosis with folic acid-binding Raman reporters has its perks, a GOpeptide quencher complex has recently been reported to be capable of detecting proteases, secreted by cells based on turn-on optical responses that could further enhance the efficacy of cancer cell diagnosis (Kwak et al. 2014). In this study, a fluorophore-tagged enzyme (matrix metalloproteinases-2, MMP-2)-cleavable peptide was covalently conjugated to the surface of GO
and its fluorescence was quenched by GO. However, in the presence of MMP-2, the peptide immobilized by GO, was cleaved and unloaded fluorophores to generate strong optical signals. The proposed platform was able to detect MMP-2 secreted from living cells, which was confirmed by adding MMP-2 inhibitor and an MMP-2 non-cleavable peptide complex.
Interestingly, in 2015, Chen et al. reported a graphene-based platform to detect cytochrome c activity in mitochondria (Chen et al. 2015) (Figure 5b). The GO-based aptameric sensor was composed of GO nanosheets; a fluorophore(Cy5)-tagged DNA aptamer and poly ethylene glycol (PEG). The cytochrome c (Cyst c)-specific DNA aptamer was non-covalently attached to GO, and it was released from GO in the presence of Cyst c. Once released, the fluorescence of the Cy5 molecule was recovered, generating perceivable level of signals using conventional optical microscopes. The GO-based Cyst c aptasensor, termed the ‘aptamer-GO nanoassembly’, could selectively distinguish Cyst c from other molecules and proteins including cysteine, isoascorbic acid, ATP, insulin, platelet-derived growth factor B (PDGF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and even immunoglobulin (IgG). The authors also confirmed that this aptamer-GO nanoassembly was able to detect Cyst c in living HeLa cells in a time-dependent manner, illustraing the potentially wide application of GO hybrid sensors for the detection of various proteins and enzymes in cells (Figure 5c).
In addition, there has been an attempt to use apatmer-GO complex to detect the presence of deleterious bacteria. Duan et al. reported an interesting study, utilizing GO as both strong FLquenching and aptamer-protecting material to detect Salmonella typhimurium (S. typhimurium) (Duan et al. 2014). Once the bacteria were added to the solution containing aptamer-GO, the aptamer adhered to the target protein on the bacterial membrane and underwent conformational changes. This results in the release of aptamer and fluorescence recovery, which indicates the
presence of bacteria. Further studies have discovered that the aptamer-GO complex could be also effective in detecting much wider strains of bacteria, including Salmonella paratyphi A (Yan et al. 2015), Salmonella enteritidis (Liu et al. 2016), Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) K88 (Ling et al. 2015) and Shigella flexneri (Zhu et al. 2015b), by using aptamer-GO alone or in combination with the endonuclease such as ApaI.
Despite their shorter history in live cell biosensing than that of other conventional nanomaterials sharing the same purpose, graphene-based hybrid materials have been proven their competency in monitoring a number of biomaterials in living cells including ions, oligonucleotides, biomolecules and proteins. This is enabled by several unique characteristics of graphene derivatives including low cytotoxicity, biocompatibility, tunable hydrophilicity, high binding affinity to SSO, and strong fluorescence-quenching ability. Considering the importance of monitoring physiological molecules, proteins, and even cells in understanding cellular activity, it is highly likely that researchers will envision other novel ways to exploit these emerging materials, especially for biomedical applications including cancer and stem cell therapies.

sections.heading: 4. Graphene-modified substrates for live cell biosensing
sections.text:
Graphene is commonly known as a very thin sheet-like material with an easily modifiable surface, and graphene-modified substrates have been intensively investigated to detect specific materials in living cells. The advantages in using graphene for live cell biosensing stem mostly from its unique physicochemical properties including adsorption to certain molecules, highly electrocatalytic characteristics, and distinct optical signals (D, G and 2D bands in the Raman spectrum) that make it an efficient signal reporter. In the following subsection, we will highlight a number of previous studies that utilized graphene-modified biosensing platforms with a
particular focus on chip-based strategies to detect several molecules (e.g. hydrogen peroxide and nitrogen oxide), proteins, and even cells (Table 2). (Preferred position for Table 2)

sections.heading: 4.1 Hydrogen peroxide sensing in living cells
sections.text:
Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a highly reactive byproduct from aerobic metabolism that must be systematically removed from cells in order to prevent damage to nucleic acids (DNA and RNA) and proteins (Droge and Schipper 2007; Lindahl 1993). However, in some cases, H2O2 is highly important for several major cell functions such as pathogen killing, tyrosine phosphorylation, and cellular proliferation (Marinho et al. 2014). Hence, precise sensing of H2O2 in living cells is necessary to fully understand complex cellular activities, which may lead to the development of effective anticancer drugs and/or cell-based therapies.
To this end, Yang et al. reported a graphene-modified hybrid substrate that showed enhanced H2O2 measurement in living cells (Yang et al. 2013). Specifically, a nitrogen and boron co-doped graphene was prepared by a microwave-assisted synthetic method and was immobilized on a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) by drop-casting. The sensor was capable of detecting H2O2 in the range of 0.5 – 1000 μM with an LOD of 0.05 μM. Thereafter, H2O2 released from CCRF-CEM leukemia cells (10 6 cells/mL) was tested for measurement. Following the addition of 1 μM fMLP, which stimulates the release of H2O2 from cells, a peak current was observed on an amperometric i-t graph, suggesting that graphene-modified GCE is a durable and reliable platform for in vitro H2O2 sensing. GQDs, which have been widely used for optical/fluorescence applications, are also effective in detecting H2O2. In one study, GQDs were attached to gold electrodes by EDC/NHS coupling, which provided peroxidase-like properties with high stability and reusability (Zhang et al. 2013c). The GQD-gold electrode showed excellent H2O2 detection
performance within the range of 0.002 to 8 mM with an LOD of 0.7 μM, which is superior to that of unmodified GO. For live cell sensing, phorbol myristate acetate (PMA) was added to trigger H2O2 release from breast cancer cells (MCF-7); the H2O2 was successfully distinguished by the developed sensing platform. Later, numerous studies utilized graphene/nanoparticle hybrid structures to detect H2O2 in viable cells. Specifically, Fang et al. introduced a magnetic nanoparticle (Fe3O4)/rGO hybrid structure that could be synthesized in a simple and costeffective manner (Fang et al. 2014) (Figure 6a). The Fe3O4/rGO nanocomposite-modified GCE exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic performance in terms of H2O2 detection within a range of 0.001 to 20mM with an LOD of 0.17 μM, which was even more precise than enzyme- or noble metal NPs-conjugated biosensors. Owing to its excellent performance, the hybrid substrate was detected H2O2 release from HeLa cells induced by a high concentration of glucose (50mM). In addition to this magnetic nanoparticle/graphene hybrid structure, Maji et al. also reported a gold nanoparticle-embedded mesoporous silica/rGO nanostructure for sensing H2O2 in living cancer cells (Maji et al. 2014). The proposed construct showed higher redox signals than both bare glassy carbon and rGO/mesoporous electrodes did, and its linear sensing range was from 0.5 μM to 50 mM with an R 2 value of 0.99848. Moreover, owing to its excellent electrochemical performance and high stability, the hybrid platform was able to discriminate cancer cells (HeLa and HepG2) from normal cells (HEK293) via electrochemical H2O2 detection. A platinum/graphene nanocomposite was also used to construct NPs/graphene hybrids (Zhang et al. 2014b), where rGO was modified on GCE followed by electrodeposition of platinum nanoparticles on an rGO/GCE electrode. The electrochemical performance of the fabricated electrode was found to be superior to several control groups including bare GCE, RGO/GCE and Pt/GCE when analyzed by CV using K3[Fe(CN)6] as a redox coupler. The linear range for H2O2
detection was 0.5-3475 μM with an LOD of 0.2 μM. It was also found that the hybrid graphenePt NPs platform was able to detect H2O2 release from living PC12 cells in the presence of ascorbic acid, which is known to stimulate H2O2 release. However, the electrochemical signals were not observable when catalase was added, indicating that the signals originated from H2O2. (Preferred position for Figure 6)
In 2015, Yu et al. also reported a strategy to detect H2O2 using horseradish peroxidase (HRP) (Yu et al. 2015) (Figure 6b) where GCE was first electrochemically modified with chitosan, and was sequentially coated with GO, poly diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA), gold nanoparticles, and HRP. This graphene/HRP hybrid platform could detect H2O2 within the range of 0.0198-1.04 μM with an LOD of 0.0075 μM. H2O2 release from K562 cells was also detected using the same sensing strategy by varying the concentration of ascorbic acid (H2O2 release stimulator) (Figure 6c). A significant decrease in signals was observed in the presence of catalase, denoting that the electrochemical signals initially originated from H2O2. In addition to grapheneNPs-modified substrates, Dong et al. also proposed a way to monitor H2O2 secretion from viable cells with MnO2-functionalized graphene paper (Dong et al. 2015). The MnO2-graphene was fabricated by simple one-step electrochemical reduction followed by deposition of GO and MnO2 nanowires. The fabricated hybrid platform was highly flexible and showed excellent electrochemical properties; it could detect H2O2 from 0.1mM to 45.4mM with an LOD of 10 μM. Encouraged by the performance for sensing H2O2, the authors attempted to detect the same molecule secreted from macrophages, by adding a synthetic peptide that is known to stimulate secretion of several molecules including interleukin 1, tumor necrosis factor, nitric oxide, and reactive oxygen intermediates (ROI). As assumed, the electrochemical signal reversibly appeared
and disappeared by adding fMLP and a ROS scavenger, respectively, when analyzed using an amperometric method.
Hence, it is obvious that graphene derivatives are excellent nanomaterials that are easily combined with other materials, such as electrodes, nanoparticles (e.g. Fe3O4, gold, platinum, and mesoporous silica), and MnO2, all of which are ultimately useful for H2O2 detection in living cells.

sections.heading: 4.2 Nitric oxide sensing in living cells
sections.text:
While hydrogen peroxide level pertains biological significance in cellular activities, nitric oxide is also an important biological molecule that is essential for the regulation of cell functions such as nervous, vascular, and immune activities (Carpenter et al. 2011). The importance of nitric oxide encompass several critical cellular activities such as tumor angiogenesis and parthenogenesis of Parkinson’s disease (Kavya et al. 2006). Hence, it is highly likely that precise detection of nitric oxide, preferably from living cells, will lead to the development of efficient diagnostic tools that enable early detection of several incurable neurological diseases, and accelerate research in cancer therapies. To this end, a number of previous studies have reported possible strategies to measure in situ levels of nitric oxide without any sacrifice to cell function/viability. Functional nanoparticles including CNTs and metal nanoparticles have been utilized to enhance the sensitivity and selectivity of platforms for nitric oxide detection (Choon et al. 2011; Priya et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2011). In addition, graphene derivatives have also recently been used for nitric oxide sensing, due in part to their superior characteristics such as low cost, high electrical conductivity, mechanical stability and biocompatibility (Yin et al. 2015). In 2012, Guo et al. introduced a RGD peptide-functionalized graphene hybrid platform for realtime monitoring of nitric oxide release from living cells (Guo et al. 2012) (Figure 7a). These
authors used GO as a supporting material and immobilized pyrenebutyric acid which underwent a GO reduction process to enhance its electrical properties. After the assembly of graphene film and further conjugation of RGD peptides to pyrenebutyric acid via covalent bonding, the platform was shown to be suitable for cell culture because RGD is excellent for enhancing cell adhesion. The graphene hybrid substrate was found to be highly selective toward nitric oxide over several other molecules such as NO2 - , K + , Na + , NO3 - , SO4 - , and ascorbic acid. Finally, the authors confirmed that nitric oxide release from human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) could be effectively detected when cells were stimulated with acetylcholine (Ach) (Figure 7b). Moreover, a gold nanoparticle-decorated rGO platform was also tested for its compliance for nitric oxide detection (Ting et al. 2013) whose linearity was discovered to be within the range of 0- 200 μM nitric oxide with an LOD of 133 nM. Subsequently, nitric oxide, released from HUVEC cells, was detected after Ach stimulation with a 0.5-2 mM Ach solution which proved that the gold nanoparticle modification assisted enhancing sensitivity for nitric oxide in viable cells. A graphene nanoparticle hybrid platform composed of metal core shell nanoparticles (Au/Pt NPs) and graphene paper was recently reported to be effective for the detection of nitric oxide (Zan et al. 2013). The developed platform was able to detect 50 nM - 1 mM nitric oxide using amperometry and was also able to distinguish nitric oxide from several interfering molecules such as ascorbic acid, dopamine, uric acid, and NO2. This graphene hybrid platform is similar to others in a way that it detects nitric oxide release from HUVECs following Ach stimulation with excellent biocompatibility. In 2015, Li et al. also introduced a new 3D hydrogel composite-based sensing material composed of gold nanoparticles and graphene sheets (Li et al. 2015). The developed sensor showed better electrochemical performance than that of the control groups including pure gold nanoparticles, pure graphene, 3D graphene hydrogels, and
gold nanoparticle-graphene hybrids. A linear relation of electrical signals and nitric oxide concentration was obtained using differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) in the range of 0.05 – 0.4 mM. Unlike the reports described above, in which HUVEC was used for live cell nitric oxide sensing, the authors cultured two different normal and cancer cell lines separately, (normal and cancer skin cells from mice), stimulated them with Ach, and finally confirmed concentrationdependent signal increases with amperometry. (Preferred position for Figure 7)
Instead of using large electrodes, Liu et al. recently developed a smaller reusable biomimetic microsensor that is composed of metalloporphyrin and 3-aminophenylboronic acid (APABA) cofunctionalized with rGO (Liu et al. 2015c) (Figure 7c). The developed sensor effectively detected very low concentrations of nitric acid (5nM) with high selectivity over several other molecules such as acetic acid, uric acid, dopamine, 5-hydroxy tryptamine, hydrogen peroxide, Larginine, and Ach. Owing to the presence of a cell-adhesive molecule (APBA), HUVECs attached and grew well on the electrode surface, which contributed to sensitive detection of nitric oxide release when cells were stimulated with L-arginine. Remarkably, due to the small size of the electrodes, the hybrid microsensor was even able to detect nitric oxide release from 4 cells based on an amperometric curve (Figure 7d).
Besides the use of large/micro electrode, there was a study to monitor nitric oxide at single cell level by using graphene-modified field-effect transistor (FET). In this study, iron-porphyrinfunctionalized rGO were used as a bridge to facilitate electron transfer between the gold electrodes that were used as the source and the drain, respectively. Based on the signals changes of drain currents, the fabricated platform was found to be able to detect nitric oxide within the range of 100 fM – 100nM with the LOD of 10 pM. The nitric oxide also could be detectable
where the HUVEC (Human umbilical ven endothelial cell) was cultured and adhered onto the iron-porphyrin-functionalized rGO bridge, proving the excellence of graphene-modified FET platform for live-cell biosensing (Xie et al. 2016).
In summary, it could be logically concluded that a graphene-based hybrid platform is not only effective in enhancing electrochemical sensitivity of electrodes used in nitric oxide sensing, but also in measuring nitric oxide release from living cells including human umbilical vein endothelial cells and mouse normal cells and cancer skin cells.

sections.heading: 4.3 Whole-cell biosensing
sections.text:
While numerous ways have been investigated predominantly to discriminate specific molecules secreted from viable cells, attempts have also been made to characterize the entire cell for cancer research, especially to capture and detect cancer cell viability in response to drug treatment, as well as to distinguish cancer stem cells from ordinary cells. In 2013, Li et al. developed an on-chip platform that selectively captures cancer cells and elucidates mRNA activity in living cells (Li et al. 2013c). In this study, the fabricated microchannel was first modified with an antibody specific to prostate stem cell antigen (PSCA). Since PSCA is overexpressed in PC-3 cells, these cells can be efficiently captured on the microchannel surface. Once cells are captured, a PEG-stabilized nano-sized GO bearing anti-mRNA as a reporter was added to monitor surviving mRNA expression in living PC-3 cells. A linear range was obtained from 100 nM to 10 μM using a cell-free configuration and then, based on this linearity, the concentration of surviving mRNA was found to be 2.7 – 8.2 μM per captured cell. In addition to this microfluidic approach, Zhang et al. reported a GO/poly-L-lysine assembled layer used to
detect leukemia K562 cancer cells using an electrochemical impedance method (Zhang et al. 2013a). The poly-L-lysine assisted cell adhesion to the electrode surface, which allowed cells, ranging from 102 to 107 cells/mL, to be detected with an LOD of 30 cells/mL using [Fe(CN)6] 3- /4- as the redox coupler. Owing to this high sensitivity, the developed sensing platform was able to assess the efficacy of an anticancer drug (Nilotinib) in K562 cells, which was consistent with that of WST-1 assays. In 2014, Manikandan et al. reported an innovative template that is capable of distinguishing normal, cancer, and even cancer stem cells based on surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) (Manikandan et al. 2014). Their gold nanoparticle-decorated graphene platform was fabricated using two different techniques; the in situ synthesis of Au nanohexgons on graphene (P1), and ornamentation of Au nanoparticles on graphene (P2), both of which were critical for enhancing Raman signals. The authors attempted to characterize normal breast cells, breast cancer cells, and breast cancer stem cells based on SERS with varying concentrations of P1 and P2, and confirmed the differences in Raman spectra. Hence, the substrate in conjunction with the Raman analyzing tool was able to discriminate cancer stem cells from other cell lines, which have been considered to be highly resistive to conventional anticancer drugs and/or cancer therapies. Later, Cui et al. introduced a new platform that was able to capture and detect cancer cells (Cui et al. 2015). Specifically, the authors reported a simple method of constructing a galactosyl anthraquinone dye that recognizes a sugar receptor, which is capable of capturing living cancer cells. Ex vivo, the developed sensor could sensitively detect peanut agglutinin (PNA), which recognizes galactose over several other materials such as pisum sativum agglutinin (PSA), mannose-selective lentil lectin (LcA), BSA, pepsin, cytochrome C, and lysozyme. Thereafter, the authors added Hep-G2 cells expressing asialoglycoprotein receptors
(ASGPr) that selectively bind to galactose, and finally confirmed a cell concentration-dependent increase of impedance signals. (Preferred position for Figure 8)
In addition to the platforms related to capturing and detecting cancer cell activity/viability, Kim et al. reported an interesting method that enabled monitoring of stem cell differentiation based on SERS (Kim et al. 2013) (Figure 8). In this study, the authors fabricated 3D graphene oxide-encapsulated gold nanoparticles that were immobilized on an ITO electrode surface. Due to the difference in the cell membrane/components between undifferentiated and differentiated stem cells, which interact differently with graphene oxide shells, the enhancement of Raman signals, especially those assigned to C=C and C-H bonds, were found to differ significantly, which enabled the monitoring of differentiation in mouse neural stem cells (NE-4C). The authors claimed that the π- π interaction between GO and cell components was critical in measuring the difference between undifferentiated stem cells and differentiated neurons/glial cells since gold NPs without GO shells failed to show much difference in Raman spectra under the same conditions. Hence, it can be concluded that graphene-based hybrid platforms are excellent for a variety of studies including capturing and characterization of cancer cells, drug screening, and stem cell-based studies.
In the subsection above, we highlighted and discussed substrate-based approaches to detect specific molecules (e.g. hydrogen peroxide and nitric oxide) and cells based on electrochemical and optical methods wherein graphene was utilized as a core material for several reasons including: i) enhancement of electrocatalytic properties, ii) unique interactions with certain molecules, iii) ease of modification of surface properties, and iv) enhancement of biocompatibility (e.g. cell adhesion and proliferation). Even though substrate-based approaches
are difficult to use for intracellular monitoring/visualizing specific materials of interest in living cells, they are highly useful for the on-chip analysis of large numbers of cells with relatively low toxicity. Hence, it is highly likely that the use of graphene hybrid materials will not only accelerate cancer studies such as cancer cell capturing, analysis, and drug screening, but also facilitate chip-based approaches for stem cell applications.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and future perspectives
sections.text:
In this review, we investigated a number of studies reporting different types of graphene derivatives for various live cell biosensing applications. We categorized these studies into two different fields: nanoparticle-based and substrate-based approaches. First, the graphene hybrid nanoparticles composed of graphene derivatives (e.g. GO, reduced GO,. and GQDs) and different types of reporter molecules (e.g. single-strand oligonucleotides, mRNA, aptamers, and molecule beacons) were found to be highly effective in detecting a variety of biomaterials in living cells, mostly relying on optical (e.g. fluorescence and FRET) methods. On the other hand, graphene-modified substrates have been utilized to detect specific biomolecules, such as hydrogen peroxide and nitric oxide, and to capture cells for further characterization, mostly depending on electrical or electrochemical methods. Graphene derivatives have recently been utilized for biosensing with other types of nanomaterials, such as metal/metal oxide nanoparticles, QDs, carbon dots, buckminsterfullerene (C60), and carbon nanotubes (CNTs). These graphene-based nanomaterials will undoubtedly gain more attention in biosensing fields, especially for live cell biosensing, owing to their desirable characteristics including biocompatibility and low toxicity, both of which are difficult to achieve using conventional tools such as QDs, CNTs, and even upconversion nanoparticles. Hence, it is highly likely that more
advanced studies will be conducted in the near future to find better ways to utilize graphene hybrid materials for live cell biosensing, which will ultimately lead to the development of methods, tools, drugs, and materials for treating numerous diseases/disorders.
